Lou and Folk -

Let me piggyback here.  The "neatest" iron tsuba I have seen 
have "wet, sticky, purplish black" patina.  I doubt this is due only 
to the properties of the base metal, but rather depend greatly on the 
care and maintenance of the tsuba.  What is it that promotes this 
type of patina?  Just so I can market the "Chicken Brand Sticky 
Purple Patina Paste".  ;o)

NC

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, JapaneseSwords@a... wrote:
> Can someone explain why many good iron tsuba are said to have a 
purplish 
> patina?  Is this just a characteristic of good early Owari tsuba or 
does this 
> cross over into other schools?  Any photos would be a great 
learning tool too.  
> Thanks in advance.
> 
> Lou
>
